examples: he spent the whole day walking
she wasn't telling the whole truth

adjective.description: In an unbroken or undamaged state; in one piece.
examples: owls usually swallow their prey whole

noun.description: A thing that is complete in itself.
examples: the subjects of the curriculum form a coherent whole
the effects will last for the whole of his life

adverb.description: Used to emphasize the novelty or distinctness of something.
examples: the man who's given a whole new meaning to the term “cowboy.”

phrases: a healthy economy is in the best interests of society as a whole
A buyer's dislike of such things can easily cloud his impression of the house as a whole.
There is no automatic reason why share prices as a whole should plummet as a result of the attacks.
It is less clear that a vote on the report as a whole would be a no confidence motion.
Many campaigners feared the loss of the venue would have an impact on youth theatre as a whole.
origin: Old English hāl, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch heel and German heil, also to hail. The spelling with wh- (reflecting a dialect pronunciation with w-) first appeared in the 15th century.
